articles.headline: Geithner Says Bailout Programs Are Shrinking
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said that many special financial programs were being scaled back.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said that many special financial programs were being scaled back.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  One year after the federal government began the biggest financial bailout in history, President Obama’s top economic advisers say the banking system has regained enough health to begin removing the government’s backstops.

articles.headline: Accountants Misled Us Into Crisis
articles.snippet: Is this an accounting-led recession? Banks masked their inadequacies, and now argue that revealing their weakness will make the situation worse.
articles.abstract: Is this an accounting-led recession? Banks masked their inadequacies, and now argue that revealing their weakness will make the situation worse.

articles.headline: Morgan Stanley Announces New Chief
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley announced on Thursday that James P. Gorman would succeed John J. Mack as its chief executive.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley announced on Thursday that James P. Gorman would succeed John J. Mack as its chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cheers echoed through Morgan Stanley when John J. Mack returned to save the soul of the bank, the bluest of Wall Street’s blue-bloods, in the summer of 2005.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Louise Story

articles.headline: Obama Factor Plays to Senator’s Advantage
articles.snippet: After surviving a sex scandal, Senator David Vitter has capitalized on Louisiana’s displeasure with the president.
articles.abstract: After surviving a sex scandal, Senator David Vitter has capitalized on Louisiana’s displeasure with the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  Mere survival was never the issue. Those familiar with Louisiana and its Republican senator, David Vitter, knew he would survive the summer of 2007, after he showed up on the client list of a Washington prostitution ring and then refused to address the matter beyond admitting to a “very serious sin” at a brief news conference.

articles.headline: Obama Faces Doubts From Democrats on Afghanistan
articles.snippet: A key Senate Democrat said that he is against sending more U.S. combat troops to Afghanistan until the training and equipping of Afghan security forces can be expanded.
articles.abstract: A key Senate Democrat said that he is against sending more U.S. combat troops to Afghanistan until the training and equipping of Afghan security forces can be expanded.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The leading Senate Democrat on military matters said Thursday that he was against sending more American combat troops to Afghanistan until the United States speeded up the training and equipping of more Afghan security forces.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Cautiously, Small Investors Edge Back Into Stocks
articles.snippet: When the financial crisis hit, some of Wall Street’s prophets warned that individual investors would be lost for years, but some of the money that fled stocks for safe harbors last year is beginning to return.
articles.abstract: When the financial crisis hit, some of Wall Street’s prophets warned that individual investors would be lost for years, but some of the money that fled stocks for safe harbors last year is beginning to return.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like millions of ordinary investors, Cindy and Eric Canup are still recovering from Wall Street’s big downturn. Their portfolio is off by 25 percent. They are mindful of their spending. And their dreams of buying land in Northern California or Oregon have been delayed five to 10 years, until they can rebuild their retirement accounts.

articles.headline: Lots of Fee Ideas for Media Online
articles.snippet: Journalism Online says it is just months away from having a payment system in place and that there is broad interest.
articles.abstract: Journalism Online says it is just months away from having a payment system in place and that there is broad interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five months ago, a group of media executives including Steven Brill seemed to have the field to itself when it said it was building a system for newspapers to charge readers for access online. Now, that group appears have a lot of company, like the News Corporation, led by Rupert Murdoch, and the technology giants Google, Microsoft and I.B.M., whose interest was first reported this week.
